Table 3 Type of enzyme Function Examples Advantages Disadvantages Esterases Hydrolysis of esters in acids and alcohols. Triglycerides are hydrolyzed to produce glycerol and fatty acids. Good efficiency in watery media and high specificity. Reduced transesterification reaction activity in contrast to lipases. Oxidoreductases Oxidation and reduction reactions for oil modification Alcohols are oxidized to carboxylic acids, and ketones are reduced to alcohols. Potential to produce goods of exceptional purity, particularly reactions related to oil modification. Cofactor need; restricted stability. Isomerases Modification in the structure of molecules while keeping the formula unchanged. Transformation of trans-fatty acids from cis-fatty acids. High selectivity: the capacity to generate specific isomers. Use limited to processes; activation requires exact conditions.. Phospholipases Hydrolysis of phospholipids Phospholipids are hydrolyzed to produce fatty acids and phosphatidic acids. Use in the alteration of vegetable oils and generation of bioactive compounds. Sensitive to surroundings; need cofactors to function. Lipases Hydrolysis of fatty acid esters and applicability in esterification and transesterification reactions. Triglycerides are transesterified; fatty acids are esterified with alcohols. Excellent selectivity and specificity; suitable for moderate pH and temperature conditions. Institute of Engineering and Sustainable Development, University of International Integration of Afro-Brazilian Lusophony Redenção CE Zip-Code: 62790970 Brazil Biolubricants are produced from renewable biological raw materials using sustainable methods, such as enzymatic catalysis and the esterification of vegetable oils and animal fats, representing a promising alternative. Enzymatic biocatalysts, in particular, have high specificity in synthesizing new products, making them a fundamental tool in producing biolubricants. This study aims to conduct a detailed bibliometric analysis to evaluate the primary studies on the enzymatic synthesis of biolubricants. It also identifies prominent countries, authors, journals, and research areas contributing to the topic. Describe the characteristics, advantages, and challenges associated with biolubricants, including the types of enzymes, substrates, and raw materials used, the mechanisms of enzymatic synthesis, and the techniques used for production, optimization, and characterization. The keywords "biofuel", "biolubricant" and "enzyme" were used for the database. The search was carried out in Scopus, covering the period from 2014 to June 2024. The analysis returned 358 articles and revealed significant international collaboration, especially between Brazil, India, and China. Brazil leads the field, contributing 19.27 % of the publications. Brazilian institutions have shown remarkable specialization in producing lubricants, using the country's rich biodiversity and biomass resources to promote research and innovation. Thus, this study presents a complete contextualization of the production of biolubricants, with an overview of world production in the area and a literature review that addresses relevant topics such as production routes and product analysis. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Biolubricant Enzymes Bibliometric analysis Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Lubricants are a significant by-product of the petroleum industry, consisting of organic compounds typically derived from mineral oils or crude oil [1]. These products are found in different forms, whether liquid, solid, or gaseous. Lubricants are primarily employed to reduce friction and possible wear on contact surfaces, such as those found in machine parts and engines [2]. In addition, lubricants play a critical role in enhancing equipment longevity by mitigating the effects of corrosion, rust, oxidation, and thermal degradation [3]. However, as a petroleum derivative, this product harms the environment [1]. It is necessary to develop alternative production routes that are aligned with sustainability guidelines. Traditional lubricants are mainly produced from mineral sources derived from petroleum and typically consist of long-chain hydrocarbons ranging from C10 to C30 in their composition [4]. In addition, it is common for additives and detergents to be mixed into the lubricant to aid lubricity performance. Given this, biolubricants emerge as a promising and sustainable alternative, as they are produced from biological raw materials [5]. It is worth emphasizing that biolubricants not only meet technical performance standards but also contribute to reducing environmental impacts [6]. In addition, their molecular structure is often based on triglycerides, which are esters of glycerol and fatty acids [7]. As a result, more studies have focused on developing methodologies for producing biolubricants [8–10]. One of these emerging methodologies is using enzymatic biocatalysts, which provide high specificity in synthesizing new products and increased efficiency and versatility in the reactions [11,12]. Consequently, it is crucial to conduct an in-depth analysis of the most suitable enzymes, their optimal reaction conditions, and the types of substrates (whether of animal or plant origin) that interact most effectively with these biocatalysts for the efficient synthesis of biolubricants [9,12]. Enzymes are used in different ways, ranging from esterification and transesterification to hydroesterification, oligomerization, and epoxidation methods [1,13–17]. Among these, esterification is the simplest and most widely used method, involving the reaction between a free fatty acid and an alcohol [18]. In this process, biocatalysts do not affect the final product's composition but maximize the yield [8,19]. Another critical point is that esterification can be conducted under milder conditions, utilizing different reaction media such as organic media [8], deep eutectic solvents [20], solvent-free press [21], ionic liquids [22], and others. The advanced bibliometrics used in this study will shed light on the progress of research on the enzymatic synthesis of biolubricants. This analysis will define the challenges and trends of research in this area and provide insights into the current scenario, which could lead to potential advances, updates, or new perspectives for improving the enzymatic synthesis process of biolubricants. Given this, it was necessary to apply a robust analysis tool, such as advanced bibliometrics, to determine the main aspects related to the enzymatic synthesis of biolubricants [23]. The advanced bibliometrics analysis applied in this study involves evaluating the quantitative indicators of published articles in a specific area of knowledge [24]. This analysis aims to identify trends and directions of scientific research over time, allowing for the recognition of contributions of authors, institutions, countries, and journals within the field [25]. Finally, this study highlights the technologies involved in producing, characterizing, and analyzing biolubricants and innovations in synthesis processes. Given this, this study is an important tool as a literature base for future research into the enzymatic synthesis of biolubricants. In addition, the following questions are answered throughout the text: • RQ1. How is the development of scientific production related to the enzymatic synthesis of biolubricants? • RQ2. Which authors stand out in the enzymatic synthesis of biolubricants? • RQ3. Which emerging subfields in recent literature are related to the enzymatic synthesis of biolubricants? • RQ4. What are the main hotspots used in the literature search? 2 Methodology 2.1 Data source This study employs bibliometric analysis as a fundamental tool for quantitatively assessing scientific production clearly and systematically, providing an accessible approach for data collection and evaluation [23]. A comprehensive data survey was performed to conduct the bibliometric analysis, compiling relevant information to construct a robust database for this study. The data were obtained from publications indexed in Scopus, one of the largest repositories of peer-reviewed scientific literature. Given the significance of this dataset, it was selected as the primary source for analysis, ensuring a comprehensive and accurate representation of the current state of research in enzymatic biolubricant synthesis. 2.2 Data collection For the database, scientific publications related to the enzymatic synthesis of biolubricants were retrieved using the keywords "biofuel," "biolubricant" and "enzyme". The search was conducted in June 2024 within the Scopus database, covering the period from 2014 to May 2024 to ensure a comprehensive quantitative assessment of research output in the field. The search was restricted to English-language publications to minimize biases related to database updates and ensure an accurate representation of the current state of knowledge. The data retrieved form the basis for the bibliometric analysis, as summarized in Fig. 1 . 2.3 Data extraction After collecting the data, all the information related to the publications was obtained, and all the material was imported into Microsoft Excel 365 software (Microsoft Corporation, Redmond, Washington, WA, United States), where it would later be processed and analyzed to present statistical results. The information considered for the development of this analysis included the frequency of citations, the relevant countries in the field of study and scientific production on the enzymatic synthesis of biolubricants, the authors, the number of annual publications, and the institutions. 2.4 Data visualization and analysis This study adopted descriptive statistical analysis of the database, considering key parameters such as authors, institutions, citation counts, and the frequency of their publications' occurrence in other works. This analytical approach allowed for a systematic and precise assessment of research output in the field. A descriptive statistical analysis was also carried out to identify patterns and trends, facilitating data interpretation and providing a structured foundation for the discussion of results. The qualitative impact of the publications was also assessed by analyzing their impact factor (IF) and journal ranking (Q1–Q4), as these indicators highlight the most relevant contributions to the field. Additionally, the number of citations was considered a measure of research influence and quality. The VOSviewer software (http://vosviewer.com) was utilized to construct network visualizations of authors, countries, and keywords, facilitating the analysis of scientific production in the enzymatic synthesis of biolubricants. The methodology was based on citation and co-citation analysis to establish relationships between these categories. This tool is widely applied in bibliometric studies to assess publications' impact and relevance and identify connections between them. The analysis considered multiple factors, including citation analysis, based on the number of times an article is referenced in other works, co-citation and co-occurrence analysis, which examine how articles are cited together and the frequency of such occurrences, and co-authorship analysis, used to identify collaborative relationships between authors. Specifically, VOSviewer was employed to: i) analyze citations by country/region.; ii) analyze citations by institution, iii) examine co-authorship and co-citation of authors; iv) assess co-citation patterns of journals; v) evaluate keyword co-occurrence. VOSviewer was again employed to construct the visual structures representing the parameters and correlations between publications. This enabled the development of clear, precise, and reliable visualizations. The figures show nodes representing key study elements—such as countries, authors, journals, or keywords—color-coded to enhance interpretability. The position and size of each node indicate its relevance within the analyzed domain, with the most significant elements centrally positioned within each cluster. Furthermore, connections between parameters are represented by linking lines, where the thickness and length of these lines indicate the strength and intensity of interactions. The Total Link Strength (TLS) metric was applied to quantitatively assess these relationships, providing a robust measure of the connection between publications.To conduct the bibliometric analysis in this study, various parameter settings were carefully considered. Key configurable parameters in VOSviewer include the origin of terms (title, abstract, keywords, and author keywords), node type (institution, author, cited author, reference, or keyword), selection criteria (e.g., top 10), and pruning of segmented networks. Additionally, customization options allow for refining term selection, node classification, filtering, and visualization settings. Bibliometrix was introduced in addition to VOSviewer to ensure comprehensive and robust analysis. While VOSviewer was primarily used for visualizing connections and relationships, Bibliometrix provided advanced quantitative analysis and statistical modeling. Specifically, Bibliometrix facilitated the identification of key trends, authorship patterns, citation networks, and the overall development of research in the field. The results obtained from both complementary bibliometric tools were integrated to provide a more nuanced understanding of the research landscape. 3 Results 3.1 Trend of global publications and citations After extracting the data from the Scopus platform, 358 publications were retrieved between 2014 and June 2024, including scientific articles, reviews, and papers presented at conferences. The evolution of the number of publications and citations over this period is illustrated in Fig. 2 , presented as both bar and line graphs. The data reveals a significant increase in publications and citations related to the enzymatic synthesis of biolubricants. Comparing 2014 with 2022, publications grew substantially—from approximately 11 in 2014 to over 60 in 2022, representing a sixfold increase. Likewise, citations saw a remarkable rise, from fewer than 100 in 2014 to nearly 2900 in 2023, marking an increase of 2800 %. 3.2 Contributions of countries/regions The provided results in this section address the first RQ: • RQ1. How is the development of scientific production related to the enzymatic synthesis of biolubricants? The map illustrates the global distribution of publications on enzymatic synthesis of biolubricants from 2014 to 2024, with the color scale representing the number of publications in each country (Fig. 3 ). Fig. 4 further highlights the top 10 countries with the most publications on the topic. Analyzing these figures reveals a global research spread, with no region dominating the field. In contrast, Fig. 5 shows the countries with the highest citation counts, highlighting the relevance and impact of their research. Interestingly, while Spain leads the list of most cited countries with just over thirty publications, Brazil, the country with the highest number of publications, ranks fifth in citations, with a relatively small gap of around 200 citations. The analysis of international cooperation in enzymatic biolubricant synthesis is illustrated in Fig. 6 , which highlights co-authorship relationships between countries. Brazil, India, and Spain emerge as key collaborators in this area. Brazil, in particular, stands out as a leading country in biolubricant research, driven by its rich natural resources and established expertise in biotechnology and green chemistry. Brazilian institutions are at the forefront of biolubricant production, leveraging the country's vast biodiversity and biomass resources. Brazil’s central position in the co-authorship network suggests it plays a pivotal role in fostering international collaborations and facilitating the exchange of knowledge and technologies. This is further evidenced by the numerous connections between Brazil and other countries, reflecting the extensive nature of its partnerships in the global research landscape. Fig. 7 presents a network diagram illustrating the global connections between countries in the field of enzyme biocatalysts, based on academic publications. Including a country in the diagram considered the presence of at least five publications and one hundred citations as minimum criteria. Out of the sixty-six countries evaluated, twenty-three met these criteria. The lines connecting the countries vary in thickness, with thicker lines representing stronger and more frequent collaborations. The diagram reveals a dense network of interconnected interconnections, organized into interconnected clusters, showcasing a global web of research interdependencies and cooperation. Brazil is highlighted as the central node in this network, located at the core of the green cluster, the most prominent on the map. This centrality underscores Brazil's significant role in the global landscape of enzymatic biolubricant research, indicating its leadership and influence in the field. Brazil’s extensive network of collaborations with numerous countries positions it as a major contributor to global research efforts. Additionally, India, Malaysia (represented in blue), and China (represented in red) emerge as other key players, although with fewer interconnections than Brazil. These countries demonstrate strong regional influence within their respective clusters, highlighting their contributions to the global research community. 3.3 Contributions of institutions Fig. 8 presents a map of connections illustrating the interactions between institutions that have made significant contributions to the field of enzymatic biolubricant synthesis from 2014 to June 2024. A total of 878 organizations were considered, with 46 institutions selected based on a minimum criterion of one publication and at least one hundred citations. The institutions are grouped into clusters based on their collaboration networks, with different colors representing distinct cooperation groups. Fig. 8 shows two main clusters that can be distinguished: the red cluster, led by the Center of Excellence, and the green cluster, headed by the Catalysis Department of the Petroleum-Chemical Catalysis Institute. These research centers naturally have the highest number of publications within the defined database, with the Center of Excellence contributing three publications and the Catalysis Department of Biosciences contributing two. However, the citation analysis reveals a different perspective when evaluating the number of citations. Three research centers stand out, and even with only one publication each, they individually reached the expressive number of 323 citations. These include the Institute of Engineering and Sustainable Development at the University of International Integration of Afro-Brazilian Lusophony (Brazil), the School of Microbiology at the Industrial University of Santander (Colombia), and the University Institute of Materials at the University of Alicante (Spain). This citation data emphasizes the significant impact these institutions have had, despite their limited publication output, within the field. 3.4 Contributions of authors The findings of this section address the second RQ: • RQ2. Which authors stand out in the enzymatic synthesis of biolubricants? Fig. 9 presents the ten most influential authors in the field of enzymatic biolubricant synthesis. The analysis considered only authors with a minimum of five publications and at least seventy citations, resulting in a selection of ten authors out of 1413 identified in the database. This number of contributing authors underscores the broad and growing interest in the subject. The diversity of authors reflects the variety of research directions within this field, covering different materials used for biolubricant synthesis, the enzymes employed as biocatalysts, and the various applications of the resulting biolubricants Next, Fig. 10 illustrates a network map depicting collaboration between authors in the field of enzymatic biolubricant synthesis. For this analysis, authors with at least two articles and 100 citations were considered, reducing the initial base of 1413 authors to 23. Key contributors include Fernandes-Lafuente (green), with 13 publications and 906 citations; dos Santos (blue), with 9 publications and 653 citations; and Freire (red), with 6 publications and 257 citations. These authors are central to their respective clusters, with Fernandes-Lafuente notably bridging multiple networks, reinforcing his prominence and expertise. This collaboration underscores knowledge exchange across regions, promoting balanced growth in the field. 3.5 Journal analysis The results obtained in this section address the third RQ: • RQ3. Which emerging subfields in recent literature are related to the enzymatic synthesis of biolubricants? Table 1 shows the ten journals with the highest contributions to enzymatic biolubricant synthesis research from 2014 to June 2024. One hundred forty-seven sources were identified in the database, and the top ten were selected based on the criteria of at least five articles published and a minimum of 150 citations. Notably, these ten journals represent 25.9 % of all publications in the field, underscoring their significance. Catalysts leads with 17 publications and 394 citations. The International Journal of Biological Macromolecules and Industrial Crops and Products published 12 articles, with 580 and 291 citations, respectively. Although the journal with the highest number of citations (1147) ranks fifth with 10 publications, its impact factor (16.799) further affirms its prominence as a primary source of influential research in this area. 3.6 Keywords analysis The results provided in this section address the fourth RQ: • RQ4. What are the main hotspots used in the literature search? Table 2 shows a ranking of the twenty most used keywords identified in the database used. Initially, 3543 words were identified, and 24 met the minimum repetition criterion of 30 occurrences, with the top 20 highlighted. Keyword analysis plays a critical role in bibliometrics, enabling the visualization of knowledge networks and the identification of research trends. Among the most frequent terms, "Biolubricants" appears 86 times, followed by "Esters" (66 occurrences) and "Nonhuman" (59 occurrences). When analyzed by Total Link Strength (TLS), "Nonhuman" emerges as the most central keyword with a TLS of 432, followed closely by "Article" (427) and "Biolubricant" (422), indicating their strong interconnections and central relevance in the field of enzymatic biolubricant synthesis. To provide a comprehensive overview of the research landscape on enzymatic biolubricant synthesis, a word cloud was created, as shown in Fig. 11 , where the size of each label corresponds to its frequency of occurrence in the dataset. This study aims to identify trends in the use of enzymes for biolubricant production while shedding light on catalysts employed in recycling plastic waste via pyrolysis, based on data from the Scopus database. Fig. 11 illustrates the 50 most frequent terms within the corpus. Fig. 12 further organizes these words into three distinct clusters, each reflecting the frequency of terms within the dataset. The size of the circles represents the importance of each word within its cluster, and the thickness of the connecting lines indicates the strength of relationships between terms. The blue cluster, for instance, highlights terms such as "Biolubricants," "Lubricant," and "Vegetable oils," which are central to biolubricant production. The red cluster includes terms like "Catalysis," "Biofuels," and "Biomass," focusing on biofuel production pathways. The green cluster, in turn, emphasizes "Enzyme activity," "Lipase," and "Fatty acid," which are associated with enzyme applications. The interconnections between words across these clusters further underscore the diversity of research and the multi-disciplinary nature of enzymatic biolubricant synthesis, with the most frequently connected words being prominently displayed within their respective clusters. Fig. 13 presents the most prominent words based on their frequency. The data reveals that these words have gained significant usage in recent years, aligning with the trend shown in Fig. 2, where an increase in publications and citations over time is observed. Notably, the legend indicates fewer words from the 2024 period, which is expected as only half a year of data is considered for that year, while the other years reflect complete datasets. By mid-2020, four words—'Biolubricants,' 'Biomass,' 'Biofuel,' and 'Catalysis'—emerged as particularly prominent, all highlighted earlier in this work. Building on the trends observed in Fig. 13, which highlights the increasing prominence of certain words over time, this study further analyzes the thematic progression of research in the field., Fig. 14 visually represents these connections through triple graphs, culminating in a Sankey diagram [26], which is commonly used for mapping the flow and temporal evolution of themes in academic research. They provide a clear illustration of how key topics evolve, allowing for the identification of shifting research priorities and emerging areas of focus. Thematic evaluation integrates this flow to understand better how fundamental concepts have changed over time [27]. From the Sankey diagram, it is possible to visualize the evolution of lines of research and the correlation of key words. In 2014 and 2015, a research trajectory emerged, with 'lipases' serving as a key starting point in this study area. Over time, this term evolved into the word 'biolubricant' between 2016 and 2018. Subsequently, the research focus split into 'biodiesel' and back into 'lipase,' reflecting the ongoing exploration of biofuels. From 2020 to 2023, 'biocatalysis' and 'biolubricant' became central, emphasizing the role of enzymes and the targeted product. In 2024, 'biolubricant' regained prominence, along with 'biofuel' and 'biodiesel.' Although 'biolubricant' appeared throughout the period analyzed, its prominence was never dominant, likely because research in this area remains in development and has not yet reached full consolidation. Moreover, the density map shown in Fig. 15 illustrates the thirty most common keywords in the field of enzymatic synthesis of biolubricants (2014–2024). The map visualizes the interactions between these keywords, with color coding representing the strength of their thematic connections. This pattern highlights the interrelationships between the keywords, reflecting their frequency and prominence in the scientific literature over the analyzed period. The analysis in Fig. 15 shows the relevance of the articles in this study's database, as all the clusters are interconnected and correlated with the subject of the study. In the blue cluster, it is easy to highlight the words biolubricant and biolubricants and vegetable oil, the primary raw material for synthesizing this biofuel. The red cluster highlights catalysts and catalysis, which are related to the use of catalysts in biolubricant production processes. In addition, the green cluster highlights lipase and enzymatic activity, which confirms the relationship between the database and the subject of this study. Furthermore, a Sankey diagram was also created to illustrate the relationships between institutions, countries, and keywords related to the enzymatic synthesis of biolubricants (Fig. 16 ). The institutions represented in the research are diverse and international, with notable universities from Brazil, Malaysia, China, India, and other countries. Key institutions include Universiti Putra Malaysia, Universidade Federal do Ceará, and Universidade da Integração Internacional da Lusofonia Afro-Brasileira. The central keywords in this research are "biolubricant" and "biolubricants," along with related terms like "biodiesel," "lipase," and "transesterification." This emphasis on biolubricants highlights a significant focus on developing sustainable and eco-friendly lubricants. Countries most frequently associated with this research include Brazil, India, China, Spain, Malaysia, Mexico, Iran, Indonesia, Canada, and the USA, corresponding to the locations of the institutions highlighted. The wide geographical distribution reflects the collaborative, global nature of biolubricant research, demonstrating thematic interconnections between institutions and keywords. For example, research on "biolubricant" is being conducted worldwide, illustrating its global appeal. Brazil and India emerge as leaders in this field, indicating a strong international presence and collaboration. The diversity of countries involved underscores the interconnected nature of this research network, which is essential for advancing biolubricant science worldwide. Lastly, the prominence of "biolubricant" and "biolubricants" emphasizes the growing interest in developing more sustainable lubricants that are environmentally friendly. 4 Overview of enzymatic biolubricant synthesis 4.1 Characteristics and benefits of biolubricants Conventional lubricants are organic compounds that can be solid, semisolid, liquid, or gaseous, derived from mineral or crude oils [1]. They are widely used to reduce friction and wear between moving surfaces in contact, such as in parts of machinery and automotive engines [2]. In addition, lubricants perform several other vital functions, including dissipating heat generated by friction, preventing corrosion, rust, and oxidation, and resisting extreme temperatures [3]. The industrial lubricants market is robust, with growing demand driven by mechanization, an increase in the fleet of vehicles in circulation, and industrial development in recent decades. In 2020 alone, investments of USD 125.81 billion were recorded in industrial lubricants, and by 2028 the global lubricants market is projected to grow at a compound annual rate (CAR) of 3.7 % in terms of revenue [1], driven by continued demand and the evolution of lubrication technologies. Currently, around 95 % of commercial lubricants' chemical composition is based on fossil mineral oils, while the remainder is made up of various additives [28–30]. Unfortunately, this dependence of lubricants on feedstocks of fossil origin results in serious environmental problems, mainly due to these products' high toxicity and low biodegradability [131]. Estimates indicate that over 50 % of the annual lubricants are discarded inappropriately through spills and/or leaks, accidents, and environmental gas emissions [1]. Inadequate disposal of lubricants can cause contamination of air, fertile soil, and, especially, aquatic environments, affecting human health and other living organisms. Feedstocks from biological sources are being explored to produce biolubricants, producing more environmentally friendly lubricants. >90 % of petroleum-derived lubricants can be replaced by biolubricants [1]. Biolubricants offer an exceptional combination of technical performance and significant environmental benefits. It has properties such as excellent lubrication to maintain the efficient functioning of mechanical components, a high flash point that increases safety in extreme temperature conditions, and low volatility that minimizes the emission of harmful vapors into the environment [10]. Additionally, the high viscosity index ensures operational consistency over a wide range of temperatures, while shear stability provides consistent performance under pressure in machinery [32–34]. Biolubricants also stand out for their low compressibility, efficiency in hydraulic systems, and resistance to humidity, which protects against corrosion and extends the machine's useful life [2,34]. Its superior dispersion capacity for various additives allows the efficient incorporation of substances such as anti-wear agents and antioxidants, which complement its functional properties [4,7]. Fig. 17 illustrates the main advantages associated with the use of biolubricants in the automotive and industrial sectors. Furthermore, these lubricants offer other attractive benefits, such as greater biodegradability than conventional lubricants, using renewable and sustainable raw materials in their production base, and low toxicity [35,36]. The biodegradability of biolubricants is a fundamental characteristic that differentiates them from petroleum-based lubricants. While conventional petroleum-based lubricants only biodegrade between 20 % and 40 %, biolubricants, especially those derived from vegetable oils, achieve impressive biodegradation rates of 90 % to 98 %, depending on the chemical composition of the oil used [37]. This biodegradation process of biolubricants occurs naturally through anaerobic processes, in which microorganisms decompose the lubricant components into simpler substances. Despite their many advantages, biolubricants face challenges such as low thermo-oxidative stability in high temperature and pressure environments and prone to solidification under low temperatures, which can affect their performance in cold climates [38]. To overcome these limitations, continuous advances in research are needed to improve their physicochemical properties and expand their use in various applications. In recent years, biolubricants have stood out due to their ecological properties and performance, making them increasingly competitive with mineral lubricants. Advances in the characterization techniques (FTIR, GC and NMR) have made it possible to accurately identify the chemical structures and compositions of biolubricants derived from vegetable oils. This makes it easier to optimize their tribological properties, such as viscosity, viscosity index, flash point, and oxidation stability [2,34]. The environmental benefits are visible, as they have superior biodegradability, low toxicity, and renewable origin, which makes them ideal for sensitive applications such as agriculture and mining. In addition, recent research shows that specific chemical and enzymatic modifications can significantly increase the performance of biolubricants, making them more resistant to oxidation and thermally stable, which is promising and close to the results presented by traditional synthetic products [38]. 4.2 Bioreactor designs and scale-up 4.2.1 Bioreactor designs Bioreactors are widely used on an industrial scale [39]. They can also be applied in the biolubricant production industry, as they provide enzymatic or fermentative catalysis in a controlled environment. These bioreactors control reaction conditions from temperature and pH to agitation [40]. These characteristics are essential for optimizing the biolubricant production process, guaranteeing a higher yield and better product quality at the end of process [41]. However, a good industrial-scale bioreactor must meet strict technical, economic, and environmental conditions [42]. Regarding bioreactors, it is important to highlight their numerous configurations since each one has its specific characteristics and can influence the production of the biolubricant in its way [43]. The type can be defined based on the catalytic method, whether enzymatic or fermentative, and the substrate used, whether vegetable oils, animal fat, or blends. Thus, the following types of bioreactors can be distinguished: Batch [44], Continuous (CSTR) [45], Fixed bed [46], and Membrane [47] (Fig. 18 ). The batch bioreactor is characterized by how the substrate and catalyst are used. The mode of substrate and catalyst utilization characterizes the batch bioreactor. At the beginning of the process, all reactants are introduced into the reactor before initiating the reaction. After a predetermined period, the final product is collected [44]. This type of bioreactor offers operational flexibility and enables precise control over experimental conditions, making it widely employed in laboratory research and small-scale production. However, compared to continuous bioreactors, batch systems generally exhibit lower productivity. In continuous bioreactors, reactants are continuously supplied while the product is simultaneously removed, resulting in a significant reduction in downtime and an overall increase in process efficiency [45,48]. An important challenge associated with continuous bioreactors is the need for real-time monitoring and control of process parameters to ensure the stability and integrity of biocatalysts throughout the production cycle. The fixed-bed bioreactor is another type to consider. In this system, the catalyst is immobilized on solid supports while the reactants flow through the bed, facilitating the reaction [49]. Unlike continuous bioreactor, the fixed-bed bioreactor allows for better separation of the biocatalyst from the reaction medium. However, prolonged operation can lead to structural degradation of the support material, and inadequate process control may result in substrate saturation, ultimately reducing reaction efficiency [46]. Another reactor that favors the separation of the biocatalyst is the membrane reactor [50]. In this bioreactor, the biocatalyst is packed in semi-permeable membranes, allowing interaction with the reactants while preventing catalyst loss. This design facilitates catalyst reuse, improving overall efficiency. However, membrane fouling can occur without precise regulation of flow dynamics and pressure, leading to a decline in performance [47]. 4.2.2 Scale-up and industrial feasibility All technology developed in biofuels aims to take innovation from the laboratory to a larger scale, the industrial scale [51]. It is essential to effectively assess possibilities for expansion and the steps and requirements to be considered in the process [52]. This expansion requires, for example, taking care of the efficiency and cost of the biocatalysts used in bioreactors. Concerning the cost of biocatalysts, their reuse must be carefully considered since the economic viability of biotechnological processes on an industrial scale depends mainly on the stability of biocatalyst after numerous reuse cycles [53]. To this end, enzyme immobilization is an indispensable tool, as it allows the enzyme to be anchored to solid supports or specific matrices, facilitating its recovery and reuse after each reaction cycle [54]. In addition, immobilization can significantly improve enzymatic activity, provide greater thermal and operational stability, and promoteains inelectivity, especially in complex reaction media [55]. In addition to enzyme immobilization, the need to scale up enzyme production must keep pace with increased demand for biolubricants. To this end, it is essential to invest in more productive expression systems, low-cost purification techniques, and protein engineering strategies that increase the yield and robustness of the enzymes used [56]. Combining these approaches can make biocatalysts more competitive compared to traditional chemical catalysts, contributing to the advancement of green technologies in different industrial sectors [57]. Another factor analyzed would be the optimization of the process, in which the reaction parameters (temperature, pressure, amount of biocatalyst, etc.) or the new project size would be optimized [58]. These parameters must be adequate to guarantee the maximum biolubricant production performance of the developed plant. At this stage, it is essential to carry out modeling and simulation, such as docking and molecular dynamics methodologies, which can describe the behavior of the reaction during the interaction of the substrates with the biocatalyst in a theoretical way. These tools are used to virtually test the proposed variations up to reliable operating coefficients without jeopardizing the physical structures of the plant [59]. For efficient scaling, the geometry and dynamics of the bioreactor must be considered [60]. These factors will affect the mass transfer and, consequently, the homogeneity of the substrate and even the temperature, being a non-linear factor, so adequate scaling is possible [61]. It is worth noting that scaling is directly linked to production capacity, requiring adjustments in the methodologies for supplying reagents and processing products [62]. With the increase in production made possible by scaling, the associated operating costs, such as energy and automation, must be considered [63]. A larger plant for greater output of biolubricants will increase all the related expenses. However, compared to other reactors, bioreactors that use enzymes as biocatalysts tend to have lower costs, as the enzymes operate under moderate pressure and temperature conditions [64]. Therefore, the feasibility of expanding bioreactors must consider many important factors to ensure efficient and safe operation. Enzymes are possible and necessary, given the need to make biofuel production processes more sustainable. The selectivity of these enzymes and the reduction in the generation of unwanted by-products guarantee a low need for disposal associated with the process. Finally, the use of theoretical modeling tools to carry out tests that do not compromise the project's physical structure. 4.3 Comparison with chemical synthesis methods The biolubricant can be produced by the chemical method, which will be discussed in this topic, and by the enzymatic method, which is the general focus of this study. These methods are different, and each has unique characteristics in terms of processes, efficiency, and environmental impact. The chemical method, also known as the conventional route, usually uses esterification and transesterification reactions, in which chemical catalysts such as acids or bases are applied [2,32,65]. For this route, high temperatures are required for synthesis, usually above 100 °C [19]. Organic solvents are used in the reaction medium to improve the solubility of the reactants, thus increasing the reaction [66]. Reactions using the chemical production route are generally considered the fastest and most economical regarding initial investment, as the catalysts used are readily available and affordable [67,68]. For example, Litsea cubeba seed oil was used as a raw material to produce a triester-type biolubricant (TFATE) through transesterification with trimethylolpropane (TMP) using a TMP-potassium catalyst. The reaction occurred in just 1 hour under optimized conditions (130 °C, 100 Pa, FAME:TMP ratio of 4:1 and 10 % catalyst). The final product, which was 92 % pure, had good lubricating properties and was qualified according to ISO VG 32 [68]. However, regarding environmental issues, the chemical route does not stand out. Aggressive reagents and solvents that are toxic to the environment are used in this production process, and the waste generated in this synthesis is another negative point, as it requires further treatment before it can be disposed of [2]. An aggravating factor in the production of by-products in the chemical route is its low selectivity, which results in a greater generation of by-products [69]. A final point to consider is the energy expenditure required to maintain the system in extreme conditions, such as temperature [70]. Regarding enzymatic synthesis, this route uses biocatalysts such as lipases, which facilitate the esterification reactions of vegetable oils or animal fats, enabling the production of biolubricants [71]. In this process, the reaction conditions are moderate, with biolubricants being produced at temperatures up to 60 °C [72]. The pH conditions are also favorable, as no bases or acids are required in the reactions (Miranda et al. 2024). Additionally, the generation of by-products is minimized, as the biocatalysts used are selective, leading to a purer product [73]. This selectivity also contributes to improved production efficiency by enhancing the conversion of raw materials into biolubricants. The enzymatic route for synthesizing biolubricants is considered sustainable as it does not require extreme conditions, does not use toxic solvents, and reduces the generation of by-products [18]. Another factor is that the biocatalysts used can be reused in new syntheses, and this reuse becomes more efficient when these biocatalysts are immobilized on specific supports [74]. In enzymatic synthesis, oils containing unsaturated fatty acids are more commonly used, as the enzymatic selectivity guarantees the integrity of these cells, making the process more efficient [75]. However, this approach still presents challenges, including the high cost of biocatalysts and longer reaction times compared to chemical processes, which can limit its industrial applicability and restrict its industrial applicability [76]. In general, enzymatic synthesis stands out from the chemical synthesis of biolubricants. Regarding efficiency and selectivity, the enzymatic route stands out because it is selective and reduces the by-products that, in the chemical route, can be harmful to the environment [77]. The reaction conditions favor the enzymatic route since this method applies milder conditions for production. The environmental impact is directly related to the generation of by-products, so the chemical route does not stand out. Unlike in terms of production cost, where the chemical route comes out on top and has the lowest initial production cost compared to the enzymatic route [78]. The duration of the synthesis process favors the use of the chemical route, as it is faster and, therefore, more attractive to industries. Given this, chemical synthesis has a well-established trend towards large-scale production under controlled operating conditions. However, this route presents challenges concerning pollution from the catalysts used and the high temperatures required, makingt it difficult to operate [79]. To counteract this situation, comparisons show that biotechnological routes, such as enzymatic catalysis, offer more sustainable alternatives, operating under mild conditions and with greater reaction selectivity, thus reducing the cost of purifying the final product. Life cycle studies (LCA) also show that biolubricants produced via enzymatic catalysis have reduced carbon emissions compared to their conventional counterparts [66]. 4.4 Types of enzymes used Exploring alternative methodologies for producing biolubricants has advanced in recent years [8–10]. The use of enzymes, cells, or catalysts from biological origin has stood out due to their specificity, versatility, and efficiency, even under mild operating conditions [11,12]. Thus, it becomes relevant to indicate the different types of enzymes used in the production of biolubricants, where each has specific functions and contributes to the alteration of vegetable oils or renewable raw materials. Table 3 provides a comprehensive evaluation of the primary enzyme classes employed in synthesizing biolubricants. Looking at Table 3, it is possible to highlight esterases, as they are widely applied in the synthesis of biofuels and the food sector, in the modification of oils or fats, and the production of aromas and flavors [78]. Esterases belong to the hydrolase family and conduct hydrolysis reactions and ester bond formation and catalyze esterification, transesterification, and interesterification reactions [80]. In the aqueous environment, this enzyme acts on the breakdown of esters, releasing fatty acids and alcohols. At the same time, it is responsible for forming esters in the organic phase, differing from lipases that hydrolyze insoluble long-chain triglycerides. In contrast, his enzyme hydrolyzes acylglycerols of the short chain [81]. Among the reaction parameters are water activity, substrate concentration, and pH, as well as the thermodynamics of the reaction [80]. This type of enzyme stands out because it does not need cofactors. Another class of enzymes is acyltransferases, which favor the green synthesis of natural products, as they catalyze regioselective acylation reactions [82–84]. Furthermore, studies report this type of enzyme's role in the final content and acyl composition of triacylglycerols [85]. Acyltransferases differ from classical lipases because they have a high affinity for nucleophiles other than water [86,87]. They catalyze acyl transfer reactions (alcohololysis, per hydrolysis, and aminolysis) in the presence of an acceptor much faster than hydrolysis (even in aqueous media with the high thermodynamic activity of water) [88]. This allows the reactions to be kinetically controlled, as the donor ester is converted into the desired product before significant free fatty acids are released. Following the discussions in Table 3, there are oxidoreductases, enzymes that play a crucial role in the catalytic transfer of electrons between molecules, making them essential for the production of biolubricants [18]. These enzymes allow the conversion of alcohols to carboxylic acids and ketones to alcohols, enabling the synthesis of biolubricants with well-defined properties [89]. Additionally, oxidoreductases mediate vegetable oils' chemical and physical modification, tailoring their characteristics to meet the specific requirements of various industrial applications [79]. Many enzymes function as electron donors or acceptors and require cofactors to operate efficiently [90]. While some oxidoreductases have applications in bioremediation, their practical use can be limited by cofactor dependency [91]. Studying the classes of enzymes that can synthesize biolubricants also mentions isomerases. These enzymes are essential and significant in drug development, organic synthesis, and biotechnology. They catalyze interconversions and are actively involved in the core metabolism of most organisms [92,93]. Isomerserases are tiny classes that solely involve molecular processes, making them simpler to study than other classes [94]. Consequently, analyzing their biological mechanisms provides valuable insights into the electrostatic principles underlying enzymatic catalysis [95]. However, further research is needed to explore their impact on liquid fuel production. Next, the class of enzymes highlighted are phospholipases, a diverse class of hydrolases present in all animals, plants, and microorganisms, and widely distributed in nature. These enzymes perform various essential biological functions, including membrane maintenance and remodeling, regulation of cellular processes, signal transduction, lipid mediator synthesis, and digestion in humans [96]. Phospholipases catalyze the hydrolysis of ester bonds in the phospholipid components of cell membranes, resulting in the production of simpler lipid molecules such as free fatty acids, lysophospholipids, diacylglycerols, choline phosphate, and phosphatidates [77]. Its potential for producing free fatty acids brings it closer to the enzymatic synthesis of biolubricants, since free fatty acids are used as the raw material for this synthesis. Thus, the lipases presented in Table 3 in the synthesis of biolubricants stands out for its applicability in the hydrolysis of triglycerides, in which fatty acids and glycerol are released sequentially [1,97]. This step is crucial, as the fatty acids produced during hydrolysis are subsequently utilized in esterification reactions with alcohols, forming stars with lubricating properties [98,99]. Interestingly, lipases typically operate under mild temperature and pH conditions, eliminating the need for harsh chemical processes. Advances in biocatalysis highlight the use of enzymes such as lipases, esterases, and phospholipases in synthesizing biolubricants. Concerning lipases, their use has proved effective in catalyzing esterification and transesterification reactions, acting on triglycerides and fatty acids to synthesize biolubricants with high specificity. In addition, immobilizing these enzymes on solid supports has increased their reusability and thermal stability, expanding their industrial application. Melo et al. (2024) [72] immobilized the lipase Eversa Transform 2.0 on Hybrid amine-epoxy core shell, and its application resulted in 97.91 % conversion into biolubricant. The reuse of this immobilized lipase was maintained with a conversion of approximately 52 % after 10 cycles. An emerging area would be genetically modified enzymes obtained through protein engineering, which makes it possible to adapt their catalytic characteristics to the desired conditions. Enzymes of microbial origin, obtained from Candida antarctica and Thermomyces lanuginosus, have been widely studied for their robustness and efficiency in esterification processes, opening up new possibilities for producing biolubricants on an industrial scale. Sousa et al. (2022) [100] used chitosan as a support for the immobilization of the lipase Eversa Transform 2.0, a lipase obtained from a strain of Thermomyces lanuginosus, and its application in the synthesis of biolubricants resulted in 40 % conversion. 4.4.1 Use of lipases in the synthesis of biolubricants Glycerol ester hydrolases, commonly known as lipases, are natural and can be sourced from animals, plants, and microorganisms [101]. Historically, lipases were extracted from animal pancreas and used as digestive aids for human consumption [102]. Today, microbial synthesis has become the preferred method for producing lipases, as it allows for better control and enhanced productivity through fermentative processes [103]. Microorganisms commonly used for lipase production include fungi from the genera Rhizopus, Aspergillus, and Mucor, bacteria from the genus Pseudomonas, and yeasts from the genus Candida [11]. While lipases from different sources can catalyze the same reaction, their performance may vary even under similar conditions [104]. Lipases exhibit stability in neutral aqueous solutions and at room temperature, with optimal activity typically observed within the temperature range from 30 °C to 55 °C [11]. Thermostability varies depending on the source, with lipases derived from microbial organisms generally exhibiting greater thermal stability [101,105]. In terms of pH, lipases generally function best within a range of 5 to 9, with optimal activity typically observed between pH 6 and 8 [76,106]. Using immobilized lipases is a strategy used to highlight their benefits and expand their applicability in industrial processes [107,108]. Immobilized enzymes are confined in space and separated by barriers that allow contact with the substrate of the reaction medium while remaining soluble in various media [109,110]. There have been notable developments in recent research on using enzymes in manufacturing biolubricants. The lipase-catalyzed esterification reaction can synthesize biolubricants from free fatty acids (FFAs) obtained from microalgae oil (Chlorella protothecoides). The researchers Kutluk T. and Kutluk B.G., optimized experimental parameters like the amount of lipase, the molar ratio of TMP/FFAs, and the reaction temperature using response surface methodology (RSM) and core compound design. This resulted in an FFA conversion of 93 % and 92 % of triesters, which was verified by gas chromatography and FTIR analysis [111]. Another significant study was conducted by Mota et al. in 2022 and examined the use of lipase-based catalysts in manufacturing biodiesel and biolubricants from microalgae. The study emphasizes the necessity of optimizing enzyme immobilization and reaction conditions to increase the stability and effectiveness of biocatalysts. It also highlights the present difficulties and potential future applications of lipases in the transesterification of microalgae oils [24]. The immobilization of porcine pancreatic lipase on activated carbon through adsorption and covalent bonding was studied by Goncalves et al. in 2021. The immobilized enzyme has enhanced efficiency and reusability in producing biolubricants, particularly butyl butyrate, which is essential for large-scale industrial applications [112]. The impact of magnetic fields on the enzymatic activity and structural conformation of the lipase Eversa® Transform 2.0 was examined by Fraga et al. in 2019. The outcomes showed that exposure to magnetic fields might enhance the enzyme's stability and efficiency throughout the biolubricant manufacturing process, offering new possibilities for enzymatic process optimization [113]. The sources of lipases, immobilization techniques, and industrial uses—including the creation of biolubricants — were all examined by Filho et al. in 2019. The study emphasizes the importance of selectinghe proper immobilization and support methods to enhance lipase activity and stability, which is necessary for the long-term sustainability and financial success of biolubricants [114]. Given the reported advantages, lipases are attractive in the catalysis of lubricating esters due to their efficient ability to hydrolyze oils and fats and their versatility in conducting esterification or transesterification reactions under mild operating conditions. Therefore, Table 4 presents work in the literature reporting the use of lipases in synthesizing biolubricants. 4.5 Immobilized or engineered enzymes to produce biolubricants The enzymatic synthesis of biolubricants has emerged as a promising line of research [76]. In this sense, Table 5 shows some immobilized or engineered enzymes, which are a determining factor for this highlight since these new biocatalysts have greater catalytic activity and stability and allow reusing them, thus reducing the associated costs. All the points highlighted here make a difference compared to free enzymes. Enzyme immobilization is a technique that consists of fixing enzymes onto solid supports, taking care to maintain their catalytic activity while acquiring stability [132]. This immobilization allows the enzyme to be reused for several synthesis cycles, contributing to cost-effectiveness [126]. In the production of biolubricants, this method is used because immobilized enzymes are more stable to variations in temperature, pH, and the use of solvents, making these biocatalysts well-suited to industries [133]. As already mentioned, the possibility of reusing the biocatalyst is another attractive feature, reducing the costs associated with the catalysts that are essential for the reactions [116]. Immobilization also aims to facilitate the separation of the catalyst from the reaction medium. This separation tends to favor reuse and increases the purity of the product, unlike the chemical route, where the catalyst tends to be associated with the production of unwanted by-products [134]. It is important to emphasize that all the points highlighted here result in the superior development of immobilized enzymes compared to their free forms [74]. An alternative to the use of enzymatic biocatalysts is the development of engineered enzymes. These enzymes are created through reaction design or directed evolution techniques [135]. Both methods aim to modify the enzyme structure, enhancing its specificity, efficiency, and stability [100]. Furthermore, these engineered biocatalysts present a promising alternative in the enzymatic synthesis of lubricants. The enzyme design technique using reaction design relies on bioinformatics and crystallography [136]. These methods enable the identification of specific mutations that can enhance catalytic efficiency or improve enzyme stability [137]. In contrast, the directed evolution technique involves random mutation cycles and the selection of variants that exhibit desired characteristics [138]. These traits may include increased stability in the presence of solvents, resistance to temperature variations, or enhanced activity under specific temperature or pH conditions [113]. It is therefore worth highlighting the importance of engineered enzymes in the enzymatic synthesis of lubricants. These enzymes are specially developed to ensure better interaction with the oils used, which may have high degrees of unsaturation or complex structures [139]. This advance in catalyst biotechnology guarantees an increase in the possibility of synthesizing biolubricants. These approaches help reduce costs, enhance sustainability, and ultimately aim to bring processes closer to industrial-scale applications [140]. 4.6 Substrates and raw materials Biolubricants are chemically "green" products that use second-generation raw materials, i.e., oils of animal, vegetable, and residual origin [5,6,141]. A variety of substrates and raw materials are necessary for the manufacture of biolubricants. The most common categories include animal fats, vegetable oils, and biomass waste [142]. Unlike petroleum-derived lubricants, these materials are popular because they are sustainable, biodegradable, and have a lower environmental impact. The exploration of raw materials used in the production of biolubricants includes the search, extraction, and processing of renewable and sustainable sources [142,143]. Due to their accessibility, favorable chemical properties, and lower environmental impact, vegetable oils are a primary renewable resource widely utilized [144]. Table 6 presents the main characteristics of the raw materials associated with the production of biolubricants. The chemical composition of oils and fats, consisting mainly of mixtures of fatty acid esters derived from glycerol, determines their effectiveness [146]. Because these oils and fats are natural organic substances, their properties vary depending on various biological factors, including light, temperature, climate, nutrient availability, moisture and water, and extraction techniques that affect their properties [147,148]. According to the literature, at room temperature, petroleum-based lubricants are inferior to natural oils derived from plants with high oleic acid content (< 80 %) [5,99]. Natural oils are compared to mineral and synthetic oils regarding lubricity, shear stability, viscosity index, and load capacity. They also have lower volatility, detergency, and better dispersion [119,148–150]. In 2020, worldwide demand for biolubricants was 4.32 million tons and is projected to reach 6.06 million tons by 2030, with a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 3.45 % [98]. Oilseed raw materials that can be used in various nations include edible and inedible oils from palm (Indonesia, Malaysia, and Thailand), castor (Brazil and India), sunflower (Ukraine, Russian Federation, European Union and Argentina), rapeseed (Canada, European Union, China, India and Ukraine), soybeans (Brazil, USA, Argentina, China and Paraguay) and Jatropha (Mexico, Thailand, India, Indonesia and Malaysia). Other sources are waste oils (China, Brazil, USA, Ireland, and Norway), animal fats from processing industries (Norway, Mexico, Ireland, Iran, and Russia), and microbial oils (China and Iran) [8,151,152]. In addition to the raw materials already mentioned above, other interesting alternatives, such as algae and other microorganisms, have been studied over time. Borah et al. [3] investigated how to use cyanobacteria and a variety of algae, such as Chlorophyceae, Rhodophyceae, and Phaeophyceae, as a source of hydrocarbons to produce biolubricants. In a study carried out on a laboratory scale, polysaccharides extracted from algae and cyanobacteria had higher molecular weight than common lubricants, better drag reduction properties, and good thermal stability due to the complexity of the polymorphic molecular structures [153]. Di Bitotnto et al. [154]. mention that sewage foam from a wastewater treatment plant contained between 36 % and 50 % lipids, with a high fraction of free fatty acids (FFAs) between 45 % and 60 %. They reported that thermal centrifugation and a chemical activation process can be used to extract between 92 % and 99 % of the lipids from sewage scum. Furthermore, according to bench-scale evaluations, esterification can convert >96 % of free fatty acids (FFAs) to fatty acid methyl esters (FAME) [1]. Papadaki et al. [155]. report in their studies that a neopentyl glycol ester (NPG), derived from microbial oil derived from a secondary stream from the confectionery and wheat milling industry, showed promising physicochemical properties for the formulation of biolubricants. The authors, in this case, refer to "microbial oil" as a secondary metabolite produced by algae, fungi, and yeast that can be used as a renewable lipid feedstock. The physical and chemical properties of biolubricants are strongly influenced by the main characteristics of the substrates, such as the composition of fatty acids, the presence of secondary compounds, and purity [18,144]. Fatty acids can be saturated or unsaturated, and this difference directly impacts the viscosity, oxidative stability, and low-temperature behavior of biolubricants [156,157]. Secondary compounds such as phospholipids, sterols, waxes, and natural antioxidants can be present in plant and animal substrates [76]. These compounds can have beneficial or harmful effects [158]. They can function as emulsifying agents, improving the miscibility of biolubricants with water, but they can also cause deposits and instability in some formulations [30,159]. Although wax can cause sedimentation and clogging of filters, it can also increase viscosity and lubricating properties. Furthermore, the oxidative stability of biolubricants is improved by natural antioxidants, which prolong their useful life and improves their performance under severe operating conditions [160,161]. Recent studies show that oils rich in unsaturated fatty acids offer better tribological performance after enzymatic modification, making them alternative substrates for biolubricants [146]. In addition, the integral use of biomass, converts lignocellulosic by-products into useful fatty alcohols and esters [154]. Non-edible raw materials, such as neem oil, have also been explored to avoid competition with the food chain, promoting an environmentally favorable approach to synthesizing biolubricants. In these applications, Wafti et al. (2020) [162], synthesized biolubricants from palm oil and the lipase lipozyme 435 with a conversion of 82 %. These results reinforce the importance of diversifying raw material for different biofuels, including biolubricants. Using vegetable oils as a raw material to produce biolubricants is a promising approach as it reduces dependence on non-renewable resources and mitigates environmental impact [18,162]. However, to increase the widespread adoption of these sustainable products, further improving production processes and addressing cost and stability challenges is crucial. A thorough understanding and evaluation of substrate characteristics and their influence on the final properties of biolubricants is essential for optimizing production and formulation processes, thereby meeting the specific requirements of various industrial applications. 4.7 Mechanisms of enzymatic synthesis 4.7.1 Biochemical processes involved in the enzymatic synthesis of esters Esterification is a reaction of great importance for the synthesis and semi-synthesis of new molecules with high added value. Prodrugs can be converted into active ingredients of commercial medications, lubricants can be synthesized, and other industries such as cosmetics, food, and materials may involve esterification steps to obtain their respective products [160]. In this context, biocatalysis offers an efficient alternative to conventional catalysis, which typically involves chemical reagents, such as acids and bases, metals, and other non-biodegradable catalysts. In contrast, biocatalysis utilizes enzymes as catalysts, providing a more sustainable and environmentally friendly option [18]. Thus, in addition to being excellent catalysts leading to high reaction yields, enzymes have high selectivity and specificity for substrates, react under mild temperature and pH conditions, eliminate the need for organic solvents, and are easily biodegradable materials [161]. The conventional mechanism for chemical esterification follows the nucleophilic acyl substitution mechanism, where alcohol reacts with a carboxylic acid to produce an ester and water in the reaction medium [162]. The general mechanism of chemical ester synthesis can be represented by Fig. 19 , where acidic catalysis leads to the formation of an ester. In step 1 of carbonyl activation, the oxygen is protonated by the acidic medium, leading to the formation of a resonance hybrid generated by the cleavage of the double bond, increasing the electrophilicity of the carbonyl carbon, making it more susceptible to nucleophilic attack by alcohol. This step can also be called carbonyl activation because, due to acid catalysis, this step becomes much faster. Next, in step 2, the oxygen of the alcohol acts as a nucleophile, attacking the carbonyl and leading to the formation of the tetrahedral intermediate. In step 3, a proton exchange process occurs, known as prototropy. This process is essential because it forms the water molecule as a leaving group, considering hydroxyl groups are not good. Finally, the double bond of the carbonyl is restored, leading to the release of the water molecule in the reaction medium, represented by step 4. Due to other water molecules in the medium, the protonated carbonyl quickly loses its its proton, leading to the information of the ester [162]. In biocatalytic esterification, the enzyme's active site is the main point of interest for understanding the mechanisms involved in this reaction. The catalytic triad that most lipases possess is formed by serine (SER), histidine (HIS), and aspartic acid (ASP) amino acids [163]. Substrates with a chemical affinity with these residues and appropriate conformations can bind to the active site and undergo catalysis. Fig. 20 highlights the active site with a lipase's catalytic triad amino acids. The substrate must approach this region for appropriate catalysis so that the carboxylic acid molecule's electrophilic atom reaches the serine's nucleophilic carbon. Weak secondary interactions with other residues near the catalytic region can be observed [164]. In the first step of the acetylation mechanism(Fig. 21 ), the electrophilic carbon atom of the carboxylic acid undergoes a nucleophilic attack by the Ser residue. Along with the nucleophilic attack, a proton transfer step occurs, where the hydrogen atom from Ser's hydroxyl group is transferred to His's nitrogen atom. This forms the first transition state. The role of Asp in these mechanisms is to increase the basicity of the His amino acid, making protonation-deprotonation events more favorable. The work of Serafim and collaborators shows that the distance between the heavy atoms of these amino acids (O and N) suggests that the proton is equally shared between these residues [165]. A gem‑diol intermediate is generated after the first transition state. In this intermediate, some secondary residues may be responsible for stabilizing the negative charge developed on the carbonyl oxygen atom of the diolate. This relatively unstable intermediate can then break down through a proton transfer step, promoted by the protonated His acting as a general acid. The collapse of this gem‑diol intermediate occurs, and in the process, a water molecule is released, leading to the acylated form of enzyme [166]. The activated acyl-enzyme, formed after the acylation process, can react with a free alcohol molecule to promote an esterification reaction, as shown in Fig. 22 . In the deacylation step, the OH group of the alcohol attacks the electrophilic carbon atom of the acylated Ser. Both nucleophilic attack steps are coupled with a proton transfer step promoted by His, which acts as a base, polarized by Asp, generating the intermediates. However, in this mechanism, the alcohol substrate is the source of the proton. In step 4, the oxygen of Ser can be protonated via prototropy or in an acid-base reaction with His, leading to bond cleavage when the carbonyl double bond is restored in step 5 [167]. 4.7.2 Selectivity and efficiency of enzymes in the context of biolubricant production The selectivity and efficiency of enzymes are crucial to producing biolubricants. Enzymes, particularly lipases, play a fundamental role in the esterification and transesterification reactions necessary to synthesize biolubricants from renewable sources [168]. These biocatalysts offer high selectivity, ensuring that responses occur at specific sites on the substrate molecules, resulting in products with desired properties and minimal side reactions [109]. One of the main advantages of using enzymes in the production of biolubricants is their ability to operate under mild conditions, such as ambient temperatures and neutral pH levels [169]. This reduces energy consumption and minimizes the degradation of sensitive compounds, thereby improving the overall yield and quality of the biolubricants. Additionally, the specificity of enzymes minimizes the need for extensive purification processes, further enhancing production efficiency [170]. The selectivity of enzymes is also crucial for determining the structural properties of biolubricants. By selectively targeting specific bonds, enzymes can produce esters with tailored chain lengths and degrees of unsaturation, which directly influence lubricating properties such as viscosity, thermal stability, and biodegradability. This precise level of control is challenging to achieve with chemical catalysts, underscoring the advantages of enzymatic processes [171]. However, the industrial application of enzymes in biolubricant production faces several challenges. Enzyme costs can be relatively high, and their activity may be influenced by factors such as substrate concentration, temperature, and the presence of inhibitors [149]. Nevertheless, advances in enzyme engineering and immobilization techniques are addressing these challenges, making enzymes more robust and cost-effective for large-scale applications [172]. Therefore, the selectivity and efficiency of enzymes are fundamental to producing high-quality biolubricants. The ability to catalyze reactions under mild conditions with high specificity makes enzymes ideal for creating sustainable and environmentally friendly lubricants. Ongoing research and development in enzyme technology are expected to enhance their industrial viability, further promoting the use of biolubricants as a green alternative to conventional lubricants. 4.8 Production and optimization techniques The production of biolubricants using enzymes has been widely studied, whether through esterification, transesterification, hydroesterification, oligomerization, and epoxidation [1,13–17]. Esterification is the most straightforward and well-known biolubricant production strategy, where the primary raw materials are free fatty acids and desired alcohols, with no significant alterations. In this process, catalysts primarily accelerate the reactions, with no yield change. The yield is instead governed by the process's thermodynamic constant (equilibrium)as it is a thermodynamically controlled synthesis method [8,19]. Esterification processes are generally conducted under low water activity conditions, such as in organic media [173], deep eutectic solvents [20], solvent-free media [21], and ionic liquids. When using a pure fatty acid to produce biolubricants, it can generally react with a specific lipase suitable for the process [37]. However, when using free fatty acids derived from oils, their chemical composition is typically not pure, as they contain a mixture of different fatty acids [174]. The use of lipases in biolubricant production can present challenges, such as the preference of certain lipases for specific fatty acids, the inability of lipases to recognize some fatty acids as substrates, and, more critically, the potential for specific free fatty acids to inhibit lipase activity [175]. Nonetheless, lipases exhibit high selectivity, which helps prevent the formation of unwanted byproducts [18]. Crude vegetable oils are promising for biolubricant synthesis due to their structural similarity to long-chain hydrocarbons found in some mineral oils, making them highly suitable for the process [2]. However, all biolubricants are susceptible to changes, especially in triacylglyceride esters [176–179]. Esterification reactions encompass free fatty acids in natural oils, which react with long-chain alcohols to form their esters [181]. Transesterification reactions, on the other hand, take place in the glycerol fractions of triacylglycerides, where a branched or long-chain alcohol replaces glycerol. Consequently, the physicochemical properties of synthetic esters are directly influenced by the alcohols or acids used in the reactions, whether esterification or transesterification [8,18]. Selecting specific lipases for each production technique is crucial to optimize biolubricant production, ensuring that the main component of the substrate combination is effectively modified [37]. Current research has already explored the combination of enzymes with different specificities, with both the yield and reaction rate [18,175]. Alcohol plays an essential role in the design of synthetic esters with biolubricant properties, making the careful selection of alcohol essential for successful biolubricant production [1]. These synthetic esters can be synthesized through the esterification of free fatty acids or the transesterification of vegetable oils, both of which bring advantages such as increased thermal stability and hydrolytic stability [7,182]. In the esterification process, free fatty acids react with specific alcohols to form the ester, which changes the fatty acids' physical and chemical properties71. Esterification and transesterification are the most commonly used and reported processes in literature, with transesterification being particularly emphasized for biodiesel production when enzyme-catalyzed reactions are discussed [183]. The transesterification process involves the exchange of the alkyl group of an ester to produce another ester. Specifically, the reaction occurs between an ester and a long-chain alcohol, making a different ester. This process can be carried out with either heterogeneous or homogeneous catalysts, which can be basic or acidic, or even without catalysts, under high-pressure, and temperature conditions14.Table 7 presents some of the processes used to produce biolubricants, their raw materials and some of the enzymes used during catalysis reactions. The work of Fernandes and collaborators 73utilizes by-products from soybean oil to produce biolubricants, employing both free and immobilized Candida rugosa lipase (CRL) for enzymatic esterification with neopentyl glycol (NPG) and trimethylolpropane (TMP) alcohols. The functional properties of the biolubricant produced were analyzed using NMR spectroscopy. CRL was immobilized on two hydrophobic supports: Accurel and a polymethyl methacrylate/polymethyl core-shell support. The results showed significant conversions, achieving up to 90 % conversion in just 6 hours using CRL immobilized on poly(methyl methacrylate), with optimal conversions maintained even after eight 24-hour cycles. Esterification reactions are particularly favored in biolubricant production due to the favorable reactivity of lipases, which exhibit high catalytic activity. These enzymes are highly promising for various substrates and reaction conditions, showing increased stability in the reaction medium [2,184].
