Hydroesterification occurs in three stages: hydrolysis,sterification, and finally, phase separation [188]. Hydroesterification produces biolubricants with high biodegradability rates, improving the physical-chemical characteristics of the final product. Additionally, unlike the transesterification process, which can lead to soap formation and reduced reaction yields, hydroesterification does not produce soaps, making it one of the fastest reactions in biolubricant production [8]. During the oligomerization process, a hydroxylated fatty acid is used, enabling the esterification of the hydroxyl group of one molecule with the carboxylic group of another, forming estolide polymers. This process is typically carried out at high temperatures [189–191]. The epoxidation process of vegetable oils is conducted at lower temperatures than oligomerization. This process involves the reaction of unsaturated fatty acids, followed by the opening of the oxirane ring. Epoxidation provides significant advantages for biolubricants, such as enhanced oxidative stability [192,193]. Even though it is rarely reported to produce biolubricants via the enzymatic route, epoxidation arises through forming peracids, or, in other cases, the modification of hydrogen peroxide occurs through an inserted double bond [17,194]. Another main characteristic for obtaining high-quality biolubricants is the viscosity index, which reflects the resistance to flow and, more importantly, the capacity of a substance to maintain its viscosity under varying temperatures. In general, a higher viscosity index indicates that the substance experiences less variation in viscosity with temperature changes [180,195]. While mineral oils exhibit excellent lubricating properties, such as good oxidative stability, their biodegradability is limited, and their viscosity index is typically around 100. In contrast, vegetable oils have significantly higher viscosity indexes and superior biodegradability. However, their oxidative stability is generally lower due to unsaturated fatty acid chains [192,196]. The study by Máximo and collaborators [197] explored the synthesis of esters using branched fatty acids, specifically 2-methylhexanoic acid. Three esters with excellent viscosity indices, around 200, were successfully produced and applied in biolubricant production: 2-octyl-1-dodecanoyl 2-methylhexanoate, 1,12-dodecanediolyl 2-methylhexanoate, and 1,10-decanediolyl 2-methylhexanoate. These esters were synthesized using mono-branched hydroxylated alcohols and linear dihydroxylated alcohols. Additionally, fifteen branched and saturated esters and diesters were obtained from 2-methylhexanoic acid, achieving optimal conversions of approximately 95 % at 80 °C within 3 hours. The esterification process was carried out in a tank reactor with a glass jacket (Vidra FOC 505/2), using the free-form Lipozyme® 435 lipase enzyme in an enzymatic process without solvents [197]. In a recent work Islam and co-workers [185] explored the use of chicken tallow as a raw material in synthesizing biolubricants, employing a two-step hydroesterification process catalyzed by Candida rugosa lipase (CRL). Chicken tallow oil was hydrolyzed in the presence of CRL to produce free fatty acids. Following hydrolysis, the free fatty acids underwent esterification, which was characterized by gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS). The esterification process involved trimethylolpropane (TMP), resulting in the formation of TMP esters. All products were analyzed using nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR). The results showed a conversion of 60 % of the hydroxyl groups in TMP, achieved in 120 min at a temperature of 35 °C, with a lipase concentration of 3 % (w/w) [185]. Although Novozym 435 is one of the most commonly used lipases for biolubricant production through the esterification of free fatty acids, other enzymes, such as Thermomyces lanuginosus lipase (TLL) Thermomyces lanuginosus (TLL) [127] and the Eversa Transform 2.0 (ETL) [126,139] have also been utilized. Most of the esterification of free fatty acids to produce biolubricants makes use of some reactors, such as the stirred batch reactor [194], microwave barrel reactor [198], and the microfluidic reactor [199]. Using lipases and vegetable oils to produce biolubricants is a cleaner and more environmentally friendly alternative than traditional chemical catalysts [151]. Despite the high costs for biolubricant production processes using vegetable oils, sustainable options, such as used cooking oils, are easily accessible in both industrial and residential settings and provide better cost-effectiveness [200,201]. It is undeniable that biocatalysts excel in optimization situations. They are immediately considered alternatives when thinking about increasing scale, productivity, and purity. Thus, various biocatalysts with different characteristics are applied to processes to optimize them. In addition, it is known that using enzymes in these processes makes them more ecological and efficient, positioning them as promising alternatives in the scientific community. As a result, enzymatic processes have gained broader acceptance in various research fields, demonstrating numerous benefits [142,180,202]. However, there is still a need for a more comprehensive exploration of biolubricant production techniques, along with the development of new methodologies. This includes optimizing factors such as reaction time, molar ratios, amount of enzymes, temperature, and the addition of performance-enhancing additives such as ionic liquids [203,204] and use of nanoparticles [205,206]. Intensified research in this area could lead to significant advances in enzymatic techniques, equipment, and processes, possibly revealing valuable insights that have not yet been fully explored. 4.9 Characterization and performance assessment To evaluate the physical and chemical properties of biolubricants, several characterization methods are used (Fig. 23 ), including Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FTIR), Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR), Gas chromatography (GC), Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), Viscosity, and Flash Point, among others. FTIR [207] is an analytical technique capable of identifying functional groups [208], organic compounds [209,210], polymeric [211,212], and inorganic [213]. NMR is another powerful analytical technique, capable of providing detailed information about compounds [214], chemical environments [215], porosity [216], fatty acid chains [217], and polymers [218]. Sharma et al. (2015) characterized two distinct biolubricants derived from canola oil and biodiesel, using specific catalysts for the epoxidation and esterification stages. NMR and FT-IR analyses confirmed the products' formation, and the biolubricants' properties were thoroughly evaluated. According to the authors, biolubricants derived from canola biodiesel were suitable for low-temperature automotive applications, whereas those from canola oil were ideal for high-temperature, heavy-duty operations with higher loads and speeds in heavy machinery. This study demonstrates that both biolubricants are effective, renewable, and possess desirable characteristics for industrial lubricants [219]. According to Pietro et al. (2020), various strategies based on ¹H, ¹³C, and ³¹P NMR spectroscopy were compared to determine free fatty acids in vegetable oils, identifying the advantages and limitations of each method used. Despite drawbacks such as sensitivity issues, signal overlap, and the need for derivatization, NMR techniques provide reliable and quantitative results comparable to conventional methods. Rent advances such as ultra-high magnetic fields and new-generation probe heads have significantly improved sensitivity and reduced noise, making NMR an even more effective tool for free acidity analysis in vegetable oils [220]. More recently, Awogbemi et al. (2022) demonstrated that waste palm oil (WPO), typically derived from frying, can be converted into biofuel, known as Fatty Acid Methyl Esters (FAME), through the process of transesterification. Using ¹H and ¹³C NMR techniques, the WPO spectra were similar to those of unused palm oil (NPO), although there were noticeable differences in signal intensities. ¹³C NMR analysis confirmed the presence of ester characteristics in the esters synthesized from WPO, demonstrating effective transformation. This suggests that used palm oil can serve as a viable feedstock for biofuel production, with NMR being an essential tool for understanding the structure and quality of these products [221]. GC is employed to analyze the composition of fatty acids [222] and other volatile components [223]. In the context of biolubricants, GC is crucial to determine the presence and proportion of specific fatty acids, such as oleic acids [224], linoleic [225], and palmitic [226], which are important for lubricating properties. On the other hand, GC analysis can reveal the amount of unsaturated fatty acids, which contribute to the fluidity and thermal stability of biolubricants [227,228]. Furthermore, the technique can identify unwanted substances [180], which can affect the quality of the biolubricant [180]. This technique is crucial as it enables highly sensitive and precise analyses to identify each compont in the bio-oil [229]. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) is an analytical technique that measures the mass variation of a material as a function of temperature or time under a controlled atmosphere [230–232]. Primarily used to study materials' thermal stability and composition, it provides information on decomposition, oxidation, and dehydration processes [233–235]. During the analysis, the material is heated at a constant rate while the mass is continuously recorded, allowing the identification of weight changes that indicate the occurrence of chemical or physical reactions [235,236]. This technique is widely used in several areas, such as polymers [237], pharmaceutical [238], and composite materials [239,240]. In the context of biolubricants, TGA allows for determining the temperature at which significant thermal decomposition of the oil occurs [235,241,242]. This information is critical for assessing the lubricant's resistance to high temperatures, indicating its ability to maintain chemical and physical stability during use under severe operational conditions [243,244]. This helps researchers understand how factors such as the chemical composition of biolubricants and the presence of additives influence their thermal stability [2,245]. Therefore, TGA quantifies the thermal stability of biolubricants and guides the development of more effective and durable formulations for demanding industrial applications. The viscosity of biolubricants is an important property that affects their performance in mechanical and industrial applications [227,246]. Derived from renewable sources such as vegetable oils and animal fats, biolubricants generally exhibit favorable viscosity characteristics that ensure the formation of a stable lubricating film between contacting surfaces [31,247,248]. This reduces friction and wear, prolonging the life of components and increasing system efficiency. The flash point of a biolubricant is crucial for determining its operational safety [158]. This measurement indicates the temperature at which the lubricant begins to release vapors that can ignite, directly indicating the fire risk associated with its use [249]. Biolubricants with high flash points protect significantly against fires, ensuring safer operation under high temperature and pressure conditions [31,250]. Studies conducted by Yelchuri et al. (2019) have shown that acylated derivatives of metathesized castor oil are promising as base lubricating oils due to their high viscosities, low pour points, and excellent anti-wear properties. These oils exhibit higher flash points than conventional lubricants, with flash points typically in the range of 165 °C to 191 °C. They are suitable for various industrial applications such as hydraulic systems and metallurgy and can be optimized with minimal additives to maximize specific performance [251]. Through these analyses, it is possible to optimize the conditions of biolubricants to enhance their properties and performance. A detailed understanding of the physicochemical characteristics of biolubricants contributes to developing more sustainable and efficient products [245]. Accurate characterization of biolubricants is essential to ensure their safe and efficient application. Modern methods such as thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), Raman spectroscopy, and automated tribological tests have been applied to determine thermal stability, wear resistance, and behavior in different temperature ranges [243,244]. These methods make it possible to compare biolubricants with synthetic and mineral products directly. Performance evaluation of biolubricants has increasingly focused on critical parameters such as friction resistance and oxidation stability, which are important for applications in high-temperature conditions [220]. Tribological tests, such as the four-ball test, pin-on-disc, and automated tribometers, have been widely used to measure the coefficient of friction and wear under controlled conditions [31,247,248]. Concerning oxidation resistance, methods such as the Rotating Pressure Vessel Oxidation Test (RPVOT) and FTIR spectroscopy analyses before and after accelerated aging have been used to measure thermal and oxidative stability. Recent results indicate that formulations with enzymatically modified lipids are more resistant to oxidative degradation thanks to reduced reactive unsaturation [251]. This extends the useful life of the lubricant and reduces the formation of sludge and acids, essential factors for the safe and efficient operation of industrial equipment. Given this, there is an indisputable need to carry out the physical-chemical characterization of biolubricants to understand their properties, performance, stability, and indispensable factors for their efficient application in mechanical systems. Techniques such as FT-IR, NMR, GC, TGA, viscosity, and flash point analysis, when applied to biolubricant samples, provide detailed information on the products' molecular structure, composition, and thermal behavior. This data not only ensures the quality and functionality of biolubricants, but also guides improvements in formulations, directly contributing to the development of alternatives to conventional petroleum-based lubricants. Thus, integrating these analytical tools into the development process is indispensable for driving innovation and ensuring the success of green technologies in the lubricants sector. 4.10 Industrial applications, challenges, and future perspectives In recent years, bio-lubricant applications broadened across multiple industrial domains [5,143,252–256]. With the energy transition process and the focus on lower emissions of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) becoming a global priority with a focus on economic and sustainable development [257], automotive engineering has emerged as the primary area for the replacement of traditional lubricants [10,258–260]. This shift is driven not only by the reduction of carbon footprint but also by the notable properties of bio-lubricants, such as thermal stability [261], low toxicity [227,262], and reduced environmental impacts, in addition to improving operational efficiency and engine performance [263,264]. Beyond automotive engineering, significant areas employing bio-lubricants include the food, maritime, and agricultural industries [265–268]. In these contexts, bio-lubricants have demonstrated their importance when used in hydraulic systems [32,269], gears, and auxiliary engines, helping to minimize the environmental impacts of oil leaks and protecting sensitive aquatic ecosystems [270]. In the food and agricultural industries [43,245,265], bio-lubricants are prioritized due to compliance with safety and sustainability standards, essential for meeting stringent regulations and reducing environmental impacts [43,227,245]. However, bio-lubricant production through enzymatic synthesis faces significant challenges that affect its economic viability and scalability [18,271,272]. Major obstacles include the high cost of enzymes [152,245], directly impacting the final cost of bio-lubricants and making their production more expensive compared to conventional methods. Enzyme stability is another issue, as many are sensitive to temperature and pH variations, which can limit their efficiency in large-scale industrial processes. Additionally, the availability and cost of renewable raw materials are critical variables [152,227,245,273], affected by regional and seasonal factors, which can compromise production consistency. Thus, recent studies have focused on using lipases and optimizing tests with various raw materials and immobilization techniques to reduce costs and improve enzyme stability [71,139,152,274,275]. Integrating these enzymatic processes into existing production plants, such as biorefineries, requires significant infrastructure, equipment adaptation investments, standardization, and scalability to ensure efficiency and economic viability for mass production [7,194,276,277]. Among emerging trends, advances in enzyme engineering stand out, aiming to modify or create enzymes that offer greater catalytic efficiency and maintain stability under adverse industrial conditions [278,279]. Techniques such as directed evolution and genetic modification are being employed to develop more robust enzymes suitable for diverse substrates [139]. Moreover, unconventional raw materials, such as microalgae oils and agricultural residues [31,118,280], areeing explored to reduce costs and enhance process sustainability [3,18]. Looking ahead to the future of bio-lubricant production, it may be transformed by integrating advanced biotechnologies, such as nanotechnology and enzymatic processes [281,282]. Synthetic biology could contribute to developing microorganisms capable of producing more efficient enzymes [281,283]. Meanwhile, nanotechnology is enhancing the enzyme immobilization step, increasing reuse potential, separation, and performance. Additionally, in the era of information storage and the transformation of data into decision-support bases, digitization and automation of production and engineering processes, utilizing technologies such as the Internet of Things (IoT) and artificial intelligence (AI), could act as high-impact factors in reducing operational costs [281,284]. Thus, enzymatic synthesis of bio-lubricants emerges as a promising technology, driven by the growing global demand for alternative fuels and products to oil by-products [285–289]. Current trends reveal significant advances in enzyme engineering for process optimization, yield improvement, and cost reduction. Future perspectives include the integration of biotechnology and artificial intelligence to develop more efficient and adaptable enzymes for various renewable raw materials [227,228,290–296]. It is also anticipated that the adoption of enzymatic bio-lubricants will expand across multiple industrial sectors, fostering a market that values energy efficiency and environmental responsibility [227,228,292]. To address these economic challenges and make bio-lubricants competitive with traditional lubricants, it is essential to integrate feedback mechanisms to implement a dynamic of continuous improvement in the industry. Through customer feedback and performance monitoring, it is possible to develop higher quality products, promote customer loyalty, and drive market growth, ensuring that market needs and technological advancements are met [180,296–298]. Innovation, such as new enzymes and alternative substrates, heavily depends on collaboration and partnerships between the private sector, companies, industries, universities, and research institutions [180,245]. Biolubricants can be widely applied in transportation, agriculture, mining, and manufacturing sectors, where reducing environmental impacts is a priority. However, their application in automotive engines still faces technical challenges, but promising formulations are already being tested. Among the main challenges are the cost of production, oxidative stability, and compatibility with synthetic materials. Future prospects are promising with advances in enzyme engineering, process optimization, and public policies favorable to the green economy. In the coming years, biolubricants are expected to become key players in transitioning to a more sustainable industry [227,228,290–296]. According to economic studies by Grand View Research, the global lubricants market is expected to grow at a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 3.8 % from 2024 to 2030 [299]. To ensure greater adoption of biolubricants and stimulate the growth of this market, it is essential to implement effective public policies. This includes creating government incentives, such as tax breaks, subsidies for research and development, and ecological certification programs that recognize and promote products with sustainable production lines. Such measures could reduce entry barriers for producers and make biolubricants more competitive against conventional oil-based lubricants. At the same time, consumer education and awareness of the environmental, performance, and safety benefits of biolubricants play a key role in transforming consumption patterns. Future prospects indicate that, with technological advances and the consolidation of economic strategies, biolubricants are likely to become an alternative in various industrial sectors. For this to happen, an integrated approach is needed that combines technological innovation, environmental regulation, incentive policies, and changes in consumer behavior, thus promoting an effective transition to the use of biofuels. 4.11 Patent analysis The analysis of patents in the field of enzymatic biolubricants is a strategic tool for identifying innovative trends, assessing the degree of technological maturity, and mapping the leading players involved in developing solutions in this area. These patents indicate the research development stage, in which the initial stage is carried out in the laboratory and results in the production of scientific articles. The final stage is aimed at the industrial sector and consequently results in the production of patents. The output of patents on biolubricants produced by the enzymatic route was analyzed between 2014 and May 2024. When researching patents, it is common to find relationships between the main themes and technological innovation, for example. The robust patent databases were used for this analysis: United States Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO), European Patent Office (EPO), the World Intellectual Property Organization, and Japan Patent Office. These databases found 80 international patents related to the production of biolubricants by the enzymatic route. Fig. 24 below illustrates the growth in the volume of patents over the years. It is important to note that the United States Patent database stands out from the others in terms of the number of patents filed. This is because this institution registers 81 % of patents. The European Patent Office follows this with 10 %, the World Intellectual Property Organization with 7.5 %, and the Japan Patent Office with only 1.5 %. These results may indicate that research in North America and Europe is more developed, resulting in more patents since robust research must be carried out before a patent can be developed. In addition, it is worth noting that patents related to biolubricants are associated with each region's need to make an energy transition. Thus, the areas with the most patents have plans for sustainable development and the search for alternative energy sources. 5 Final considerations The bibliometric analysis applied in this study was fundamental in providing a panoramic view of scientific production involving the enzymatic synthesis of biolubricants. As a result, it was possible to determine that Brazil is the country that has published the most on this subject in recent years. Much of this is due to its natural wealth, which provides countless raw materials for application in this production line. A reflection of Brazil's prominence is seen in the authors' analysis, where four of the top ten are from Brazilian institutions. Following on from the institutions, it is possible to notice the prominence of these South American institutions. This is in line with the country's analysis of production. This data is consistent with each other and reinforces the quality of this study. The analysis of journals highlighted the journals Catalysts and International Journal of Biological and Macromolecules, which are the leading journals in the area, according to the delimitations made. These delimitations pointed to areas related to the enzymatic synthesis of biolubricants, such as biodiesel production and the application of enzymes. What can be seen from this information is the evolution of the lines of research within the collaboration groups. Thus, it is likely that biolubricant research has developed from other more consolidated lines of study, such as biodiesel synthesis. With the results presented, the enzymatic synthesis of biolubricants has emerged as a promising alternative to conventional processes but still faces challenges that limit its commercial expansion. The main obstacles are the high cost of enzymes, especially commercial lipases, and the difficulty scaling up laboratory processes for industrial applications. Although immobilizing enzymes is a relevant strategy for increasing their reusability and stability, the limitations maintaining catalytic activity over multiple cycles still compromise technical feasibility. The lack of regulatory standardization must be considered, as it hinders the insertion of these biolubricants on the market, and their performance in real operating conditions, such as in engines and industrial systems, still needs to be better validated. On the other hand, emerging and little-explored areas offer new opportunities to boost this field. Using enzymes modified by protein engineering, exploiting alternative raw materials such as agro-industrial waste, and integrating biocatalysis with clean technologies can reduce costs and increase the sustainability of processes. However, the lack of specific public policies, low investment in applied research, and limited interaction between academia and the productive sector could lead to stagnation. Overcoming these barriers will require a multidisciplinary and articulated approach involving science, technology, regulation, and incentives for innovation in the context of the bioeconomy. coredata.dc:description: Biolubricants are produced from renewable biological raw materials using sustainable methods, such as enzymatic catalysis and the esterification of vegetable oils and animal fats, representing a promising alternative. Enzymatic biocatalysts, in particular, have high specificity in synthesizing new products, making them a fundamental tool in producing biolubricants. This study aims to conduct a detailed bibliometric analysis to evaluate the primary studies on the enzymatic synthesis of biolubricants. It also identifies prominent countries, authors, journals, and research areas contributing to the topic. Describe the characteristics, advantages, and challenges associated with biolubricants, including the types of enzymes, substrates, and raw materials used, the mechanisms of enzymatic synthesis, and the techniques used for production, optimization, and characterization. The keywords "biofuel", "biolubricant" and "enzyme" were used for the database. The search was carried out in Scopus, covering the period from 2014 to June 2024. The analysis returned 358 articles and revealed significant international collaboration, especially between Brazil, India, and China. Brazil leads the field, contributing 19.27 % of the publications. Brazilian institutions have shown remarkable specialization in producing lubricants, using the country's rich biodiversity and biomass resources to promote research and innovation. Thus, this study presents a complete contextualization of the production of biolubricants, with an overview of world production in the area and a literature review that addresses relevant topics such as production routes and product analysis.
